Comments_List: I learned the cutting edge techniques in decision theory.
Topics in decision theory and proof techniques/sketch of some important conclusions about statistical inference.

This was a fun course. I learned a lot. I think there could be some optional assignments or guided reading to help people stay involved, while realizing that the material is difficult and shouldn't necessarily be graded.
Topics were carefully chosen and class materials were well organized.
I think it's better if there are some kind of notes, because the materials are quite hard.

Strength: Harry knows the material very well and can answer every single question in class. The proof is always presented in a clear and natural way, and the techniques (for showing bounds) are introduced as well. The only weakness might be that there is too few practice, but this is also sensible by the nature of the class.

If the student is interested in theoretical Econometrics, this course is important because it opens your mind to net tools and perspectives developed in the statistical literature that can be combined to economic models and incorporate endogeneity problems.

If you have the prerequisite knowledge, definitely. If not, you won't be interested. It's not worth taking if you aren't going to be able to follow the lectures. If you think you can, definitely take it and just absorb as much as you can-- it's a great experience.
Yes. Note that this course has no assessment, so you need to be self-motivated otherwise you may get totally lost in the course
Yes, any class taught by Harry would be a great experience to one interested in theory. Harry is my favorite professor at Yale.
